Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of California Los Angeles, in partnership with the University of Oregon and the Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD), propose an extension to the Into the Loop Alliance. The goal is to build and support the capacity of the LAUSD to offer high-quality, college preparatory computer science classes, especially in high schools with high numbers of African-American and Latino students, and to develop a model and repository of best practices that can help spread and inform similar efforts to other school districts nationwide. The project is committed to affecting the depth and scale of change that is necessary to integrate the teaching and learning of computer science into the national education enterprise with the intent of engaging all students. Their focus is on the secondary school level because this is when students are being prepared for pursuing their careers and interests in college. Into the Loop proposal builds upon five previous years of accomplishments, most notably the creation of the Exploring Computer Science (ECS) curriculum and the ECS teacher professional development program. The scope of work for years 6-10 is focused on:

-- Deepening, institutionalizing, and sustaining the reforms in the LAUSD;
-- Expanding the research base and designing authentic assessment measures for student engagement with and learning of computational
thinking practices;
-- Creating and evaluating resources for best and promising practices around ECS curriculum and pedagogy, teachers professional
development and learning community, and ECS assessments; and
-- Studying the scalability and replicability of ECS curriculum and PD.

In years 6-10, the partnership will serve as a national resource for others pursuing CS education/broadening participation in computing initiatives.

ProgramReference.Text: Computer Science for All (CS for All)

POR.DRECONTENT:
Why are so Few African-American, Latino/a, and Female Students Learning Computer Science?

Into the Loop Alliance was awarded in 2008. It was submitted at a time when very few classes and/or pathways for learning computer science (CS) existed in the nation?s high schools. Those that did exist revealed disparities that fell along race and socioeconomic lines. The grant was designed to research the underrepresentation in CS and to increase and enhance CS learning opportunities in the second largest school district in the country, the Los Angeles Unified School District (LAUSD). Our work rested on prior research described in Stuck in the Shallow End: Education, Race, and Computing (MIT Press, 2008, 2017) that describes how CS education has long been a window into the production and reproduction of inequality and how students of color, low-income, and female students become underrepresented in the field.  

The primary accomplishment of our Into the Loop grant was the creation and expansion of the introductory high school Exploring CS (ECS) program that included both 1) curriculum introducing students to the broad field of CS and 2) an accompanying ECS teacher professional development (PD) program. The creation of ECS curriculum (co- authors Joanna Goode and Gail Chapman) was in response to our finding that often in schools with high numbers of students of color, introductory CS classes focused only on the most rudimentary skills such as typing and word processing. ECS, on the other hand, was designed to introduce students to the problem-solving, creativity, and computational practices of what CS really is. Our mission was to assure that ECS existed in schools in underserved communities with high numbers of students of color. The ECS PD supports a teachers? learning community and adoption of inquiry-based and culturally responsive pedagogy that builds on the culture and knowledge that diverse populations of students bring to the classroom. ECS includes topics in to Human-Computer interaction, Problem-Solving, Web Design, Introduction to Programing, Computing and Data, and Robotics. See: www.exploringcs.org

Into the Loop grant first introduced ECS by partnering with LAUSD, expanding from 6 to 32 schools in a short period of time. Following this, ECS expanded nationally over the next decade. A big step forward took place when educators from Chicago Public Schools attended ECS PD in LA and brought ECS back to Chicago, where the course became a requirement for graduation. University of Oregon (UO) has led ECS expansion in recent years and ECS is now taught in at least 34 states and Puerto Rico, including the 7 largest school districts, as well as some rural locations and reservations. Further, over 55,000 students participated in ECS courses nationwide in 2018?19, with an additional 6,000 expected in 2019?20. Into the Loop also contributed to the growing national CSforAll movement.

Over the last couple of years, the work of Into the Loop grant was extended and deepened by two newer NSF multi-year grants: 1) REAL-CS (Researching Equity, Access and Learning in CS Education) which is a Collaborative Research grant awarded to UCLA and UO. This grant supports the ECS program (led by UO), the and local and statewide policy committed to CSforAll (CSforCA, SCALE-CA led by UCLA), and student voice research focused on the development of student agency and voice in CS learning (led by UCLA). A second grant, SCALE-CA, further supports California policy efforts. See: https://centerx.gseis.ucla.edu/computer-science-equity-project/  These grants support a research agenda committed to furthering our mission of broadening participation in computing.

Intellectual Merits and Broader Impacts

We believe that one of most important contributions of our Into the Loop grant was to demonstrate how equity and broadening participation in computing can be the driving force and core principle of CS learning in partnership with educators in local school districts. We early on contributed the language for talking about equity in the context of CS education. Our practices in ECS modeled research-based effective educational equity practices. As a result, interdisciplinary (CS and education/social science) expertise has become an expected norm for NSF CS education projects.

Broader Impact

Into the Loop and ECS have prepared over 3500 high school teachers through extensive PD and through these teachers, reached hundreds of thousands of students through introductory ECS curriculum. This work has led to the NSF Mobilize grant that created an Introductory to Data Science (IDS) curriculum that has become a national model of how to introduce data science in partnership with local high schools. Because of the reality of how the world is being impacted by big data and CS innovation, CS and data science becomes more relevant for how we live our professional and personal lives and increasingly important for all students to learn. This knowledge is necessary for more diverse population of students to become leading voices in positions of power through community advocacy, and civic participation, and computing-related careers.
